title: 'Urgent' need for power plan: Origin's Calabria
text:
Mr Calabria will reiterate concerns voiced at The Australian Financial Review National Energy Summit earlier this month that a decade of energy and climate policy "inertia" and ad hoc measures have made it difficult for a board to commit to major capital investments in new generation needed to fill in the gaps between wind and solar power.

He will say that the current maximum price limit in the wholesale market is neither ensuring enough investment in reliable supply nor protecting energy users against high prices.

Mr Calabria will say that while one cannot conclude that the National Electricity Market "is broken beyond repair", policy makers and industry need to agree on what is needed so see the country through the transition to clean energy.

He will take issue with government participation in the energy sector through the Snowy 2.0 pumped hydro project and the underwriting scheme for new on-demand generation, as well as with the federal-NSW government task force that could result in a further extension in the life of AGL Energy's ageing Liddell coal generator in NSW.

"We need to recognise that coal is the wrong type of generation to firm renewables and extending the life of old coal plants without a strong carbon signal will extend the uncertainty we are all facing today," he will say in comments that counter the push by Federal Energy Minister Angus Taylor to lengthen the life of coal generators.

Extending coal power also has the effective of "denying the inevitability of the low emissions future we know we will need to deliver for our customers and the community if we are to minimise the impacts of climate change," Mr Calabria says.

The comments come as the Energy Security Board, the federal government's top policy advisor, is starting to consult on the reforms needed in the NEM to ensure reliable supply amid increasing penetration of wind and solar amid.

The work has sparked debate as to whether the NEM needs to switch to a so-called "capacity" market where owners of coal and gas plants can be paid to keep capacity available, even if they don't run. Other options being considered include a reserve of coal generating capacity that is kept outside the NEM.

We need to recognise that coal is the wrong type of generation to firm renewables... — Frank Calabria, Origin Energy CEO

Mr Calabria says an incentive is likely to be required for "firming" generation but calls for "the full suite" of capacity mechanisms to be examined. It is also important that capacity markets aren't viewed as a "panacea", he says, noting that some, such as the UK's, have been "plagued with issues".

He argues that any capacity payments "need to go hand-in-hand with a strong carbon signal, to minimise distortion in the market, deferring further investments and increasing the costs to customers".
description: Origin Energy chief executive Frank Calabria has revived calls for a market mechanism in the electricity sector that combines emissions and reliability goals.
